Situation A. Gabriel’s Claim: Finding the Volume of Prisms

Gabriel’s Claim

We compared the volumes of the prisms, but we did not find the volume.

I think that we can use our strategy for the rectangular prisms.

Imagine putting unit cubes inside each prism.

  • We can find the number of unit cubes that fill that would fill the base.
  • Then, we can multiply this by the height to find the volume.

This should work for all right prisms.
1. Test Gabriel’s claim to find the volume of the prisms in the Initial Challenge.

Answers will vary based on the size of the paper used for the experiment.

See answers in previous chart for an 8 1/2 x 11 inch sheet of paper.
2. Using this strategy, what is the relationship between the volumes of the prisms?

The volumes increase as the number of sides increase.

Students may see the same relationship as the experiment. Others may not have been able to see the relationship because the experiment may have been too inaccurate.
3. Will her strategy work for all prisms?

Yes.

The area of the base tells how many unit cubes would be in a slice of the cube that is 1 unit tall. The height is how many of those layers would be used to make the prism. So if you multiply the area of the base times the height, you will get the volume.

Situation B. Applying Your Strategy

Use your strategies to find the volume and surface area of each right prism.

All of the prisms have height 12 inches and the base areas are different, so the volumes are different.

The volume of the triangular prism is half the volume of the rectangular prism (cutting the rectangular prism on the diagonal of the base would create two triangular prisms).

The volume of the hexagonal prism is the greatest.

Volume of the rectangular prism is (5 x 8) x 12 = 480 in.3 ;

Volume of the triangular prism is (8 x 5 x 1/2) x 12 = 240 in.3 ;

Volume of the hexagonal prism is 166 x 12 = 1992 in.3 .

Note:

Students do not have enough knowledge to find the area of a hexagon, so the area of the base is provided for them. In Grade 8, students will find the area by noting that the six triangles that make up a regular polygon are equilateral triangles and that the height of each triangle divides its base in half. Applying the Pythagorean Theorem to the right triangle gives the height: approximately 6.93 in. Each triangle has area 27.72 in.3 , so the base area is 6 x 27.72 = 166.32 in.3.
1. Suppose you want to use another identical sheet of paper to make a prism that has a volume greater than any of the prisms in the Initial Challenge. What might it look like?

Answers will vary:

Any right prism, whose base has more sides than octagon, will have greater volume. Nonagon, Decagon, Dodecagon, … are some examples. Students might also come up with cylinder, which is ultimately of the greatest volume.
2. How does its surface area compare the surface areas of prisms in the Initial Challenge?
The area of sides is constant and the area of base increases as the number of sides of base increases. So, the surface area of larger prisms is greater than those in the Initial Challenge.

Situation D. Gabriel’s Claim

Do you agree with Gabriel? Explain.

Gabriel’s Claim

I know that one way to find the volume of a square prism is to find the number of unit cubes that fill the bottom and then multiply this by the height to find its volume. I think the same method will work for all rectangular prisms.
